data.description: On August 9, 1877, gunshots shattered a chilly dawn on a sleeping camp of nımí·pu· (Nez Perce). By the time the smoke cleared on August 10, almost 90 nimí·pu· were dead, along with 31 soldiers and volunteers. Big Hole National Battlefield was created to honor all who were there.
data.directionsInfo: Big Hole National Battlefield is located on Highway 43 ten miles west of the town of Wisdom in southwestern Montana. Bear Paw Battlefield is located on Route 240 sixteen miles south of the town of Chinook in north-central Montana.

operatingHours.description: The grounds and trails at Big Hole National Battlefield are open daily from sunrise to sunset.
operatingHours.name: Big Hole National Battlefield

images.title: Battlefield at Dawn
images.altText: Multiple tepee poles and a river are silhouetted against a dawn sky.
images.caption: Today tepee poles stand sentinel at the site of August 9th, 1877 dawn attack at the Big Hole.

images.title: Camas Blooms Near the Nez Perce Camp at the Big Hole
images.altText: Blue camas flowers dot a green field with tepee poles in the background.
images.caption: The Nez Perce chose their camp site in the Big Hole in part due to the Camas, whose roots they gathered prior to the August 9th attack.

images.title: Mountain Howitzer at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: a cannon overlooks a valley and distant mountains
images.caption: Nez Perce warriors captured and dismantled the Mountain Howitzer cannon before the US army could use it effectively at the Battle of the Big Hole.

images.title: Monument to the US Soldiers and Volunteers at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: cross country skis rest against a large granite monument on a snowy day.
images.caption: In 1883 the United States Government erected this monument in honor of the soldiers and volunteers that served and died at the 1877 Battle of the Big Hole.

images.title: Chief Joseph Memorial at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: Stone carving of a Nez Perce Warrior's head in full regalia.
images.caption: This monument, erected on the Big Hole Battlefield in 1928, reads; "To the everlasting memory of the brave warriors Chief Joseph's Band who fought on these grounds in the Nez Perce War of 1877."

images.title: Bear Paw Battlefield
images.altText: Three large stone monuments and four interpretive signs overlook a series of low hills.

data.weatherInfo: This climatic region is typified by large seasonal temperature differences, with warm to hot (and often humid) summers and cold (sometimes severely cold) winters. Wisdom has a humid continental climate.
data.name: Big Hole

data.description: The vast, wild landscape of Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area offers visitors unparalleled opportunities to immerse themselves in the natural world, and experience the wonders of this extraordinary place. With over 120,000 acres, one can find an astounding diversity in ecosystems, wildlife, and more than 10,000 years of human history to explore.
data.directionsInfo: Bighorn Canyon has two districts that are separated by a three hour drive. To get to the North District at Fort Smith, MT from Billings, take Interstate 90 south to Hardin, MT. Turn at exit 495 onto State Highway 313 to St. Xavier and then to Fort Smith, Montana. To get to the South District at Lovell, WY from Billings, MT, take Interstate 90 west. Turn at exit 434 at Laurel, MT. Turn onto US 310 East/US 212 South. Turn at US 310 East to Lovell. The visitor center is on the east side of Lovell.

operatingHours.description:
The park is open every day. 

The Yellowtail Dam Visitor Center in Fort Smith, MT is only open in the summer from Memorial Day to Labor Day. 

The Cal S. Taggart visitor center in Lovell, WY operates on seasonal hours;
Summer Hours (Memorial Day to Labor Day): 8:30 AM to 4:30 PM; Seven days a week.
Winter Hours (Labor Day to Memorial Day): 8:30 AM to 4:30 PM; Tuesday through Saturday. Closed Sundays and Mondays.
operatingHours.name: Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area

operatingHours.description: The Cal Taggart Visitor Center is opened Tuesday-Saturday from 8:30am-4:30pm.
operatingHours.name: Winter Hours: Lovell, WY Visitor Center

addresses.line1: Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area South District Visitor Center
Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area South District Visitor Center

images.title: Yellowtail Dam (Fort Smith, MT District)
images.altText: Summer view of the Yellowtail Dam from the Ok-A-Beh road.
images.caption: Summer view of the Yellowtail Dam from the Ok-A-Beh road. (Fort Smith, MT District)

images.title: Spring Cactus
images.altText: spring cactus with yellow flowers
images.caption: Spring Cactus

images.title: Kayaks at Barry's Landing (Lovell, WY District)
images.altText: Four orange kayaks laying with their tips on the red rocks at Barry's Landing.
images.caption: Kayaks at Barry's Landing ready to go. (Lovell, WY District)

images.title: Bighorn Sheep Overlooking the Canyon
images.altText: Bighorn Sheep Overlooking the Canyon
images.caption: Bighorn Sheep Overlooking the Canyon

images.title: Devil Canyon Overlook from Sullivan's Knob Trail (Lovell, WY District)
images.altText: Looking up canyon toward Devil Canyon from the rim at Sullivan's Kob.
images.caption: Devil Canyon Overlook from Sullivan's Knob Trail (Lovell, WY District)

images.title: On The Lake
images.altText: smooth water just south of Barry's Landing
images.caption: A Great Day on the Lake

images.title: Horseshoe Bend from the Sykes Mountain (Lovell, WY District)
images.altText: Red hills in the foreground with Bighorn Lake in the background with a brilliant blue sky.
images.caption: Horseshoe Bend from the Sykes Mountain (Lovell, WY District)

data.weatherInfo: North District: Semi-arid, receiving 18 to 20 inches of rain annually. South District: High-desert, receiving 6 to 10 inches of rain annually. Summer temperatures: Highs in the 80s (F) and 90s (F), lows in the 50s (F) and 60s (F). Summer temperatures can peak over 100 degrees. Winter temperatures: Range in the 20s and 30s with low temperatures averaging the 10s (F) and 20s (F). During the winter the thermometer can drop below 0 (F) with extreme wind chill factors.
data.name: Bighorn Canyon

data.fullName: Fort Union Trading Post National Historic Site
data.description: Between 1828 and 1867, Fort Union was the most important fur trade post on the Upper Missouri River. Here, the Assiniboine and six other Northern Plains Tribes exchanged buffalo robes and smaller furs for goods from around the world, including cloth, guns, blankets, and beads. A bastion of peaceful coexistence, the post annually traded over 25,000 buffalo robes and $100,000 in merchandise.
data.directionsInfo: Located on North Dakota Highway 1804 right at the Montana and North Dakota state line. From Williston, ND, approximately 25 miles to the southwest via ND Highways 2 & 1804. From Sidney, MT, approximately 25 miles to the northeast, via MT Highways 200 & 58. Commercial flights and rental cars are available in both Williston, ND and Sidney, MT. Amtrak passenger train service and rental cars are available in Williston, ND.

operatingHours.description: Park Hours are 9:00 - 5:00 Central Time Daily
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.title: River View of Fort Union
images.altText: View from Missouri River bottoms of Southwest bastion
images.caption: Viewing Fort Union Trading Post from the Missouri River bottoms one can imagine how grandiose the site would appear to weary steamboat travelers.

images.title: Twilight View of the Bourgeois House
images.altText: Candles illuminate the Bourgeois House porch at dusk
images.caption: Volunteer reenactors relax on the Bourgeois House porch

images.title: Fort Union Trading Post Courtyard
images.altText: Courtyard of Fort Union Trading Post with Bourgeois House, Tipis and US Flag
images.caption: Ranging from employee housing, workshops, storage warehouses, domestic animal pens and horse corrals, the courtyard housed the world at Fort Union.

images.title: Fort Union and the Missouri River Valley
images.altText: View of Fort Union and the Missouri River looking south
images.caption: Visitors hiking the scenic Bodmer Trail experience a historical view of Fort Union, and the same view painted by Karl Bodmer in 1833.

images.title: Tipis fill the fields around at Fort Union
images.altText: White canvas tipis in grassy area, Fort in background.
images.caption: During the height of the spring trade season camps from various Upper Missouri Tribes would fill the plateau around Fort Union.

data.weatherInfo: Weather in western North Dakota can be harsh, with extremes in temperature and sudden, violent storms. Be prepared for rapidly changing conditions. Summers are warm with average high temperatures in the 80s-90s May through September. Winters are cold with average lows in the single digits December through February. Wind is considerable year-round. Conditions can change quickly. Travelers should be aware of the potential for violent thunderstorms in the summer and the possibility of blizzards.
data.name: Fort Union Trading Post

data.description: A showcase of melting glaciers, alpine meadows, carved valleys, and spectacular lakes. With over 700 miles of trails, Glacier is a paradise for adventurous visitors seeking a landscape steeped in human culture. Relive the days of old through historic chalets, lodges, and the famous Going-to-the-Sun Road.

entranceFees.description:
(Winter Rate - $25.00, November 1 to April 30)
This is an entrance fee for all persons traveling in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van). The pass is good for seven days and is non-transferable. Visitors can enter the park at any time, if the entrance station is not staffed, a self-registration area is available for purchasing a 7-day park pass.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description:
(Winter Rate - $15.00, November 1 to April 30)
This is a per person entrance fee for a visitor traveling on foot, bicycle, or for individuals traveling together in a vehicle as a non-commercial, organized group. The pass is good for seven days and is non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description:
(Winter Rate - $20.00, November 1 to April 30)
This is a per motorcycle entrance fee. The pass is good for seven days and is non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Entrance fees are based on the seating capacity of the vehicle (driver not included). Commercial Sedan entrance fee is $25, plus $20 per person, 16 years of age or older. The pass is good for seven days and is non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: Entrance fees are based on the seating capacity of the vehicle (driver not included). Commercial Van entrance fee is $75 regardless of occupancy. The pass is good for seven days and is non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: Entrance fees are based on the seating capacity of the vehicle (driver not included). Commercial Mini-bus entrance fee is $100 regardless of occupancy. The pass is good for seven days and is non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: Entrance fees are based on the seating capacity of the vehicle (driver not included). Commercial Motor Coach fee is $200 regardless of occupancy. The pass is good for seven days and is non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entrancePasses.description: New in 2024, all passes will have one signature line for a single passholder. This pass is valid for one year from the month of entry and admits the purchaser and passengers in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or the pass holder and his/her immediate family (spouse, children, parents) when entry is by other means (foot, bicycle) into the park. It is nontransferable, nonrefundable, and does not cover camping fees.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Glacier National Park is located in the northwest corner of Montana along the spine of the Rocky Mountains. By car you can access Glacier via Highway 2, which runs along the southern boundary of the park. You can reach the east side of the park via Highway 89. The nearest airports are in Kalispell and Great Falls, Montana.

operatingHours.description: Glacier National Park is open 24 hours a day 365 days of the year. An entrance fee is required, even when entrance stations are not staffed. Instructions are available at each entrance for self-payment.
operatingHours.name: Glacier National Park

images.title: Glacier Lilies near Logan Pass
images.altText: Large mountains dotted with snow loom above a rocky meadow filled with yellow flowers.
images.caption: Glacier lilies dot the landscape off the Highline Trail.

images.title: St. Mary Falls
images.altText: A double waterfall blurs over layered rocks.
images.caption: Glacier National Park is sculpted by water.

images.title: Lobby of the Lake McDonald Lodge
images.altText: Looking down into the lobby of the Lake McDonald Lodge from the balcony
images.caption: Lobby of the historic Lake McDonald Lodge

images.title: Alpine Sunset
images.altText: Clouds of orange and red sit above dark-gray mountains; snow dots the mountain peaks.
images.caption: Majestic Heavens Peak is easily viewed from the Going-to-the-Sun Road.

images.title: Swiftcurrent Fire Lookout
images.altText: A small, brown and white structure sits on a rocky top with mountain peaks in the distance.
images.caption: The historic Swiftcurrent Lookout was built in a Swiss chalet architectural style.

images.title: East Side Sunset
images.altText: Jagged peaks rise out of a forested valley and an empty road curves off into the distance.
images.caption: Going-to-the-Sun Road in the St. Mary Valley

images.title: Glacier's Night Sky
images.altText: Silhouetted mountains and flowers against a night sky filled with stars and a milky band of light.
images.caption: Glacier's dark sky is important to wildlife and people.

data.weatherInfo: Glacier's weather is highly variable and can be extreme. Expect warm, sunny summer days but be ready for any type of conditions. In the winter, temperatures can fall well below freezing and typically the park receives considerable amounts of snow. Glacier's geography, straddling the Continental Divide, sets the stage for clashes of two very different climates. Warm, wet Pacific air moves in from the west, and cold, dry Arctic air flows from the northeast. They meet at the Divide.
data.name: Glacier

data.description: Wide open spaces, the hard-working cowboy, his spirited cow pony, and vast herds of cattle are among the strongest symbols of the American West. Once the headquarters of a 10 million acre cattle empire, Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site preserves these symbols and commemorates the role of cattlemen in American history.
data.directionsInfo: Arriving from the east: Take Interstate 90, exit 187. Drive through town, approximately 2.5 miles. Turn left onto Grant Circle and enter the park. Arriving from the west: Take Interstate 90, exit 184. Turn right. Drive approximately 3/4 of a mile. Turn right on to Grant Circle and enter the park.

operatingHours.description: Hours for the main historic area of Grant-Kohrs Ranch, the Visitor Center and Interpretive Ranger programs.
operatingHours.name: Historic Area Operating Hours

images.title: The Ranch House
images.altText: A front view of the ranch house.
images.caption: The front portion of the ranch house was originally built by Canadian fur trader Johnny Grant in 1862.

images.title: The Ranch House
images.altText: A view of the rear of the ranch house.
images.caption: The rear portion of the ranch house was an addition put on by Conrad Kohrs in 1891.

images.title: Deer Lodge Mountain
images.altText: Deer Lodge Mountain rises up over the pastures of Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site.
images.caption: Deer Lodge Mountain, and the rest of the Flint Creek Range, directly influence the weather in the valley below.

images.title: Reveal
images.altText: Fenced green pasture in front, 3 ranch buildings across center, blue sky with large white clouds.
images.caption: Many people are surprised by the first glimpse of the historic ranch buildings.

images.title: Cattle Herd Moving
images.altText: Herd of cattle moving from back right to front left in front of historic buildings
images.caption: The ranch cattle herd contains Hereford, Shorthorn and Texas Longhorn, which were popular breeds during the Open Range Cattle Era

images.title: Cowboy on Horseback with Cattle
images.altText: Historic buildings surround fenced pasture, cattle being moved by cowboy on horseback toward viewer.
images.caption: The American Cowboy developed during the Open Range Era and became a cultural icon.

data.weatherInfo: Spring: Temperatures can fluctuate greatly. Sub-freezing temperatures in the morning can give way to mild days. Snow in early spring, rain in late season. Summer: Temperatures can average 70-80 F, but can reach highs of 100 F. Rain rare. Dry and hot. Fall: Temperatures can fluctuate greatly. Sub-freezing mornings can give way to mild days. Rain in early fall likely. Winter: Temperature can fall to -30 F, with highs of 10-20 F. Snow is possible. Cold weather gear is highly recommended.
data.name: Grant-Kohrs Ranch

data.fullName: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail
data.description: At the end of the last Ice Age, 18,000 to 15,000 years ago, an ice dam in northern Idaho created Glacial Lake Missoula stretching 3,000 square miles around Missoula, Montana. The dam burst and released flood waters across Washington, down the Columbia River into Oregon before reaching the Pacific Ocean. The Ice Age Floods forever changed the lives and landscape of the Pacific Northwest.
data.directionsInfo: To Trail Headquarters from Spokane Take I-90 West At Exit 277, merge onto US-2 toward Davenport/Fairchild AFB/Spokane Airport Just past Wilbur, turn right onto WA-21 Stay left onto Highway 174 Turn right onto WA-155 Stay on WA-155 past Grand Coulee Dam and into the town of Coulee Dam Cross the Columbia River and continue on WA-155 Turn right onto Crest Drive and follow up the hill. The HQ Office is located on the left

operatingHours.description: The Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail is a collection of sites operated and owned by a variety of partners. , Hours of operation and season will vary from site to site. Please check each respective site for more details and information.
operatingHours.name: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail

addresses.line2: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail
Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail

data.description: The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail winds nearly 4,900 miles through the homelands of more than 60 Tribal nations. It follows the historic outbound and inbound routes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1803-1806 from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to the Pacific Ocean. Follow the trail to find the people, places, and stories that make up the complex legacy of the expedition.
data.directionsInfo: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center is located inside DOI, National Park Service, Interior Region 3,4,5 Office. We are right on the Missouri River next to the Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge in downtown Omaha, NE.

operatingHours.description: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center is located on the Missouri River in Omaha, Nebraska.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours

images.title: Giant Springs
images.altText: Small waterfall with brown rocks and green moss
images.caption: Giant springs is a site along the Lewis and Clark National Historic Site located in Great Falls, Montana

data.weatherInfo: In winter, watch for ice on trails and sidewalks. In summer, make sure to drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen on hot days. Keep in mind the Trail covers 16 states, use www.weather.gov to look up the specific area you plan to visit.
data.name: Lewis & Clark

data.description: This land is a place to honor and reflect on the sacrifices made here on June 25 and 26, 1876, when Lakota, Cheyenne, and Arapaho warriors fought against a deliberate attack by the U.S. Army's 7th Cavalry, led by Lt. Col. George Custer, who sought to enforce policies that threatened their traditional way of life. How are the results of the battle felt in the West and Indigenous communities today?

data.directionsInfo: Take Interstate I-90 and exit at the Crow Agency Exit 510 at Jct. 212. To reach Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument, turn right at the park entrance onto Battlefield Tour Road 756.

exceptions.name: Closed for the New Years Day

operatingHours.description:
Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument winter season hours begin October 1. The park is currently closed Monday to Thursday. 

The temporary contact station, bookstore, entrance gate, and Custer National Cemetery are open from 8 am to 4 pm on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday. 

The 4.5 Mile Tour Road, Last Stand Hill, the Indian Memorial, the Reno-Benteen Entrenchment and Deep Ravine Trail are open from 8 am to 3:30 pm on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday.
operatingHours.name: Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument Winter Season Hours

images.title: Indian Memorial
images.altText: The sun sets behind the Indian Memorial.
images.caption: The Indian Memorial is a circular earthwork carved gently into the prairie. The walls carry the names of those who fell here as well as the words of some who fought in the battle.

images.title: Headstones in the winter
images.altText: Headstone can still been seen even with the fresh snow that blankets the battlefield .
images.caption: The monument and battlefield are open year round, even in winter when snow coats the ground.

images.title: Stone House
images.altText: The stone house sits on the edge of the Custer National Cemetery.
images.caption: The stone house once served as a house for the Superintendent and their family. It has been renovated and  restored and now serves as an office and research area.

images.title: Seventh Calvary Memorial at Dusk
images.altText: The Seventh Calvary Memorial at dusk.
images.caption: About 40 to 50 men of the original 210 were cornered on the hill where the monument now stands.

images.title: Rising Full Moon
images.altText: A rising moon peaks above the eastern horizon in January.
images.caption: Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument moon rising above the Indian Memorial

data.weatherInfo: Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument average weather: Spring: 50-60 (F) degree days/ 30+/- (F) degree nights Summer: 70-100 (F) degree days/ 45-60+ (F) degree nights Fall: 40-50 (F) degree days/ 25+/- (F) degree nights Winter: 20-30 (F) degree days/ 0+/- (F) degree nights
data.name: Little Bighorn Battlefield

data.description: Since time immemorial, the valleys, prairies, mountains, and plateaus of the inland northwest have been home to the nimíipuu (Nez Perce) people. Extremely resilient, they survived the settling of the United States and adapted to a changed world. Nez Perce National Historical Park consists of 38 places important to the history and culture of the nimíipuu. Explore these places. Learn their stories.
data.directionsInfo: Driving south bound on U.S. Highway 95 you will find the Visitor Center 10 miles from Lewiston, ID. Roughly one mile after crossing the Clearwater River you will find the park entrance on your left. When driving north on U.S. Highway 95 the Visitor Center will be 3 miles north of Lapwai, ID. The park entrance will be on your right.

operatingHours.description: Summer visitor center operating hours are 8:30 am - 4:00 pm daily. In the winter, the visitor center is open 5-days a week from Tuesday - Saturday from 8:30 am - 4:00 pm.  Closed Sunday and Monday.  The visitor center is closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's days.
operatingHours.name: Nez Perce National Historical Park, Spalding Visitor Center

images.title: Painted Tipi
images.altText: Colorful painted tipi on green lawn
images.caption: Every morning in the summer Rangers put a tipi on the front lawn of the visitor center. Visitors are always welcome to help.

images.title: Buffalo Eddy
images.altText: Petroglyph carvings on the bank of the Snake River.
images.caption: Buffalo Eddy contains many petroglyphs and is considered a ancient crossing place.

images.title: Take Flight
images.altText: Birds in flight across a grassy field.
images.caption: Birds take flight across a grassy field.

images.title: Buffalo Hide Tipi
images.altText: Elder (Mylie Lawyer) sitting in front of Old Buffalo hide tipi.
images.caption: The only known remaining complete buffalo hide tipi belonging to a Nez Perce.

images.title: Appaloosa Horse Parade
images.altText: Horses and riders dressed in native regalia.
images.caption: This horse parade was held in the Spalding picnic area during the parks 50th anniversary in 2015.

images.title: Weippe Camas
images.altText: Blue Camas flowers in a prairie field.
images.caption: Camas has been a food staple of the Nez Perce for thousands of years.

data.weatherInfo: Elevations in the Park range from 700 feet above sea level to over 8,000, providing a wide range of climatic conditions, that follow the four seasons. Be prepared for very warm weather in the summer months, in particular in the river valleys. The spring and fall are moderate and comfortable. Winter conditions can be severe in the higher elevations, with snow and ice making travel difficult and dangerous. Please visit the National Weather Service for comprehensive weather information.
data.name: Nez Perce

data.description: On March 1, 1872, Yellowstone became the first national park for all to enjoy the unique hydrothermal wonders. Today, millions of people come here each year to camp, hike, and enjoy the majesty of the park.

emailAddresses.description: Contact Yellowstone's park rangers for general park questions, lost and found, or for special use permits.

entranceFees.description: Unlimited entry for one vehicle and all passengers for seven consecutive days, beginning on the day of purchase. Vehicles must be private, non-commercial, and with a seating capacity of 15 or less.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial group (e.g. church groups, scouts) traveling in a vehicle with a capacity of 16 or more people. Cost is per person. Unlimited entry for one vehicle and all passengers for seven consecutive days, beginning on the day of purchase.

entranceFees.description: Entry for one driver and one passenger for seven consecutive days, beginning on the day of purchase.

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The cost is $25 + $20 per person. Pass is good for seven days as long as it's the same passenger group.

Pass is good for seven days as long as it's the same passenger group.

A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Pass is good for seven days as long as it's the same passenger group.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: Based upon the total capacity of a vehicle that can carry 26 or more passengers, regardless of the actual number of passengers. A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Pass is good for seven days as long as it's the same passenger group.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entrancePasses.description: Provides unlimited entry for one year (valid through the month of purchase) to the pass holder and passengers in the same vehicle, or pass holder and up to three persons where per person fees are charged. Purchase at any entrance station.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Yellowstone National Park covers nearly 3,500 square miles in the northwest corner of Wyoming (3% of the park is in Montana and 1% is in Idaho). Yellowstone has five entrance stations, and several are closed to regular vehicles during winter. It takes many hours to drive between these entrances, so be sure to check the status of roads at the entrance you intend to use while planning your trip and before you arrive.

operatingHours.description:
Yellowstone is open daily, year-round, although activities and services are limited at night and certain times of year. The park has five entrance stations, but not all entrance stations are open year-round. Make sure to carefully read about access at each station at different times of year. And remember, all dates are weather-dependent.

Please note that camping is possible only in designated campgrounds.
operatingHours.name: All Park Hours

operatingHours.description: Adjacent to the town of West Yellowstone, Montana, the West Entrance is usually open (weather-dependent) to wheeled vehicles from the third Friday in April through early November, and to tracked-oversnow (snowmobiles and snowcoaches) vehicles from December 15 to March 15.
operatingHours.name: West Entrance

operatingHours.description: Near the gateway community of Gardiner, Montana, the North Entrance is the only park entrance open to wheeled vehicles all year. November through April, the North Entrance provides the only access to Cooke City, Montana. US Highway 212 east of Cooke City is closed to wheeled vehicles November through April. The road from Mammoth to Norris opens to wheeled vehicles the third Friday in April through early November, and to tracked-oversnow vehicles, conditions permitting, from December 15 to early March.
operatingHours.name: North Entrance

operatingHours.description: Depending on the weather and conditions, this entrance usually opens to wheeled vehicles the first Friday in May and to tracked-oversnow vehicles December 22 through March 15.
operatingHours.name: East Entrance

operatingHours.description: Open (weather-dependent) to wheeled vehicles from the second Friday in May through early November and to tracked-oversnow vehicles from December 15 to March 15. Limited services are available near the South Entrance.
operatingHours.name: South Entrance

operatingHours.description: Near the gateway communities of Silver Gate and Cooke City, Montana, this entrance is open year around for wheeled vehicle access to Cooke City through Gardiner, Montana. US Highway 212 east of Cooke City is closed to wheeled vehicles November through April. Opening dates for roads east of Cooke City vary from year to year, depending on the weather. The Beartooth Highway is open from late May/early June (weather dependent) to mid October.
operatingHours.name: Northeast Entrance

images.title: Grand Prismatic Spring
images.altText: Brilliant blues and greens of a hot spring ringed by oranges, yellows, reds, and browns.
images.caption: The bright colors found in Grand Prismatic Spring come from thermophiles—microorganisms that thrive in hot temperatures

images.title: Aurum Geyser
images.altText: A crowd of people standing along a wooden boardwalk watches a geyser erupt.
images.caption: Aurum Geyser erupting

images.title: Black Pool
images.altText: A visitor stands on a boardwalk near a hot spring and a lake.
images.caption: Black Pool at the West Thumb Geyser Basin

images.title: Beehive Geyser
images.altText: People on a wooden boardwalk watch a geyser erupt.
images.caption: Visitors to the Upper Geyser Basin watch Beehive Geyser erupt.

images.title: Wolf howling
images.altText: A wolf howls while standing on a snowy field.
images.caption: Alpha male of the Canyon wolf pack

images.title: Fishing Bridge Trailside Museum
images.altText: Visitors walk into a rustic, log and stone building.
images.caption: The stone-and-log architecture of Fishing Bridge Trailside Museum became a prototype for park buildings all around the country

images.title: Great Fountain Geyser
images.altText: A geyser erupting in the middle of a large pool.
images.caption: Great Fountain Geyser erupts against a blue summer sky

images.title: Old Faithful Geyser in winter
images.altText: A crowd in front of an erupting geyser during a snowy winter day.
images.caption: Winter is a magical time to watch Old Faithful Geyser erupt

images.title: Palette Spring
images.altText: Visitors walk in front of a brightly colored, terraced landscape.
images.caption: The vibrant colors of Palette Springs are formed by thermophiles—heat-loving organisms

images.title: Bighorn sheep
images.altText: Two bighorn sheep laying on the ground.
images.caption: Two bighorn rams rest and chew their cud

images.title: Lower Falls from Artist Point
images.altText: A river plunges into a steep, barren canyon.
images.caption: Lower Falls from Artist Point

images.title: Bison herd in a thermal area
images.altText: A herd of bison grazing through a barren and steaming thermal area.
images.caption: Bison near Mud Volcano

images.title: Grizzly bear
images.altText: A grizzly bear standing on a fallen tree.
images.caption: Grizzly bear in the woods

images.title: Yellowstone River
images.altText: A greenish river meanders through a hilly river valley.
images.caption: The Yellowstone River near Tower Fall

data.weatherInfo: Yellowstone's weather can vary quite a bit, even in a single day. In the summer, daytime highs can exceed 70°F (21°C), only to drop 20 or more degrees when a thunderstorm rolls through. It can snow during any month of the year, and winter lows frequently drop below 0°F (-18°C), especially at night. Bring a range of clothing options, including a warm jacket and rain gear, even in the summer.
data.name: Yellowstone
